ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



CTI is a culinary driven food manufacturer that takes pride in being first in class for developing new products for our customers. Our culinary team is on the cutting edge when it comes to new flavors and trends, but also stays close their roots of classic training, and the technical R&D team is among the best in the business when it comes to product development, improvement, matching, re-engineering and production scale-up.



Our product development skills are fully complemented by strong manufacturing and quality assurance teams within each of our production locations. Utilizing the latest technologies and production processes, our products are efficiently produced while keeping quality and food safety first of mind.



At CTI Foods, our goal is to develop long-term relationships with foodservice organizations. By being leaders in the areas of food safety, product development, process innovation, and customer service, we are adequately prepared to offer food solutions to all segments of the foodservice business. In doing so, we will help grow YOUR brand, as it ultimately is our brand as well.



The CTI Foods management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  CTI Foods' safety and environmental policies are administered by the Senior Engineer, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the OSHA Process Safety Management and EPA Risk Management Program.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The CTI Foods facility is located at 504 Sansom Boulevard, in Saginaw, Texas.  The facility is approximately 0.4 miles east of South Saginaw Boulevard (Highway 287) and 0.9 miles north of Interstate 820.    



The regulated material present at the facil

ity is anhydrous ammonia.  The facility uses approximately 50,801 pounds of ammonia as a refrigerant within a closed system.  The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for cold storage, freezer storage, and dock areas.  The majority of the system is located in the Engine Room including the vessels and compressors.  The condensers are mounted on the roof, and the evaporators are located in their respective cold storage areas.  The ammonia refrigeration system was constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the International Fire and Mechanical Codes at the time of construction.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:



1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and

2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).



These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by CTI Foods to prevent the accidental release of ammonia at the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia system is operated safety.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measu

res are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that the CTI Foods employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.



It is important to note that the refrigeration system been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors in the Engine Room and cold storage areas, which will alert operators of an ammonia leak.  



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



A review of the facility's accident history revealed that there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the last five years (November 2007 - November 2012). In addition, there have been no releases of ammonia that meet the RMP definition of "accident" as described above.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



The CTI Foods facility has an emergency response plan in effect.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) has been developed by CTI Foods and designed to meet

the following objectives:



  1.) To save lives.

  2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

  3.) To protect the environment.

  4.) To minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan is reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.



The CTI Foods facility coordinates emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis, performed on August 19, 2010, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the CTI Foods facility located in Saginaw, Texas.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The CTI Foods facility is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
